topics.topic_title: Attributes of a Person or Thing
topics.overview: This topic discusses qualities, characteristics or features that define a person or thing. It explores physical attributes of a person such as height, weight, eye colour, complexion and personality traits such as kindness, honesty, patience, confidence.
general_competences: Communication: Use appropriate language when describing a person or a thing in French
Communication: Express oneself clearly, effectively and take turns when conversing with others
Emotional intelligence: Express empathy for other people
Emotional intelligence: Relate effectively with others as they discuss their different personalities
topics.hook: Display a set of images of animals or objects depicting different emotions, sizes, colours and other qualities. Ask the learners to describe each one of them using adjectives they already know e.g petit/e, grand, content.

sub_topics.title: Colours
sub_topics.introduction: This sub topic focuses on colours. Colours are one of the first vocabulary sets learners learn. They are easy to visualize and use in everyday life, making them a great starting point for language learning. Knowing colours helps learners to describe objects, clothes, food and the world around them.
competences: 1.6.1.1: Express preferences for colours in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Identifying colours of objects (rouge, jaune, verte)
teacher_steps: Provide a dialogue on colours
Provide different objects with colours mentioned in the dialogue for learners to see
Introduce other colours to the learners (vert/e, gris, jaune, orange etc)
learner_steps: Learners listen to a dialogue/conversation on colours and identify the names of colours in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing one's preferences for colours (j'aime/ je n'aime pas la couleur verte)
teacher_steps: Conjugate le verbe 'aimer' and préférer
Explain la négation 'ne…. pas' structure
Guide learners to construct sentences using 'ne … pas' for their colour preferences
learner_steps: In groups, learners talk about colour preferences using the verbs 'aimer' and 'préférer (positive and negative form)
Learners construct sentences using 'ne … pas' for their colour preferences

instructional_blocks.hook: Drawing and coloring the Flag of Zambia
teacher_steps: Guide learners to mention colours of the Flag of Zambia in French
learner_steps: Learners mention colours of the Flag of Zambia in French
Learners draw the Flag of Zambia and label the colours in French

sub_topics.short_notes: Colours in French: Les couleurs - vert/verte, rouge, orange, noir/noire blanc, blanche (masculin/féminin) rouge, jaune, bleu/bleue, brun/brune, marron, rose. Content tips: Colours that end with '-e' do not change form according to gender e.g le pantalon rouge, la robe rouge. Some colours agree in gender and number with the noun e.g Un sac bleu - des sacs bleus, Une robe verte - des robes vertes. If a noun is feminine, many colour adjectives take an '-e' at the end e.g une robe bleue, une pomme verte. Some colours change form to agree with the noun's gender and number e.g blanc(m)/blanche(f) e.g un mur blanc, une robe blanche.

questions: Express preferences for colours in French correctly

sub_topics.title: Physical Characteristics and Personality
sub_topics.introduction: This subtopic will enhance learners' communication skills, understanding of cultural contexts and will enable them express themselves with confidence as they describe characteristics of a person and objects by using adjectives related to traits in French.
competences: 1.6.2.1: Describe someone's physical characteristics and personality in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Identifying physical characteristics and personality (cheveux longs, les yeux bruns)
teacher_steps: Draw 'le corps humain' and label the external parts in French (la tête, les cheveux, les yeux, le nez, les oreilles, la bouche etc)
Guide learners to read and pronounce the body parts in French correctly
learner_steps: Learners read and pronounce the body parts in French correctly
In groups, learners identify the physical characteristics of people from the images or pictures displayed

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing adjectives in French
teacher_steps: Provide sentences in French in which adjectives describing physical characteristics of a person or thing have been used
Guide learners to identify adjectives used in the given sentences
learner_steps: Learners identify adjectives used in the given sentences

instructional_blocks.hook: Describing a person or an object using information provided
teacher_steps: Guide learners to describe a friend or family members
Discuss irregular adjectives (adjectives ending in - x,-f, -er, -on, -en, -el, and il)
learner_steps: In pairs, learners describe a friend or family members using the vocabulary learned
Write a guided composition on describing a person using a picture

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing the expressions used to describe ones personality
teacher_steps: Introduce adjectives used to describe ones personality (heureux, intelligent, content/e, paresseux)
learner_steps: Learners role-play describing someone's personality e.g. Mon frère est calme, Ma mère est timide

sub_topics.short_notes: Physical characteristics vocabulary: la tête, les cheveux, les yeux, le nez, les oreilles, la bouche. Expressions: Il/Elle est comment? Comment est-il/elle? Il/elle est petit/petite, grand/grande, gros/grosse, mince. Grammar: Le comparatif - Il/Elle est plus +(adjectif) que, Il/Elle est moins+(adjectif) que. Adjectives must agree with the thing they are describing in gender and number. Add an 'e' to the describing word if the word being described is feminine. Adjectives ending in 'e' don't need to add an extra 'e' when dealing with gender.

questions: Physical characteristics and personalities described correctly

topics.overview: Numeracy refers to the ability to understand, interpret and work with numbers and mathematical concepts. Numbers are a basic and essential part of any language. Understanding numbers in French helps learners to engage in practical communication through practical usage of numbers in real life situations.
general_competences: Communication: Learners will use numbers during their everyday conversation in different situations
Critical Thinking: Learners will explore how French speakers structure numbers in a unique way thereby recognizing numbers and their pattern relationships
Problem Solving: Learners will develop skills that help them budget, save and make smart financial decisions
topics.hook: Imagine you are in Paris, standing in a bakery and want to buy two croissants. The baker asks, 'combien en voulez - vous?' you know what you want, but how do you say the number in French? Without your numbers in French, you might end up with twelve instead of two.

sub_topics.title: Cardinal Numbers (0 - 1000)
sub_topics.introduction: Cardinal numbers are used constantly in everyday life when expressing age, quantity, prices, time and dates. They are building blocks for learning ordinal numbers as they are a foundation for other number types and mathematical operations.

instructional_blocks.hook: Listening to numbers in French
teacher_steps: Teacher counts objects or items in French. E.g. un, deux, trois, quatre, cinq
Display a chart with objects and their numbers in French
learner_steps: Learners listen and count after the teacher with correct pronunciation
In groups, learners count different items in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Identifying numbers from 0 to 1000 in French
teacher_steps: Display a chart with numbers in French (zéro to cent)
learner_steps: Learners identify the numbers ending with -ze-, -nte- and group them accordingly

instructional_blocks.hook: Counting cardinal numbers from 0 to 1000
teacher_steps: Guide learners to count from 0 to 100
learner_steps: Learners count from 0 to 100
In groups, learners use flashcards to compete in identifying numbers in French
In pairs, learners ask each other's phone number in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Write numbers in French from 0 - 1000
teacher_steps: Guide learners to write numbers in French
learner_steps: Learners write numbers in French from 0 - 100
Learners match the numbers in figures to numbers in French

sub_topics.short_notes: Numbers from 11 (onze) to 16 (seize) end with 'ze'. Numbers from 17 to 19 are ten-seven (dix-sept), ten-eight (dix-huit) and ten-nine (dix-neuf). 30, 40, 50 and 60 in french end with 'nte' (trente, quarante, cinquante, soixante). 70 is sixty-ten (soixante-dix). 80 is four 20s (quatre-vingts). 90 is four 20s-ten (quatre-vingts-dix). In between numbers are like in English e.g. vingt-deux, vingt-trois. Except for 21: vingt et un, 31: trente et un, 41: quarante et un.

sub_topics.title: Ordinal Numbers (first to twentieth)
sub_topics.introduction: In French, ordinal numbers are very important as they help learners to know the position, ranking and order. Ordinal numbers help learners form more natural sentences and improve their ability to understand instructions, sequence and narratives.
competences: 1.7.2.1: Demonstrate knowledge of ordinal numbers from 1 to 20 in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Listening to a passage on ordinal numbers and identify them
teacher_steps: Provide a passage or dialogue which contains ordinal numbers
Explain the meaning of ordinal numbers used in the passage or dialogue
learner_steps: Learners identify ordinal numbers from the passage or dialogue

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing Ordinal numbers and their endings (ième)
teacher_steps: Explain the formation of Ordinal numbers
Add -ième to the cardinal number to get deuxième (second), troisième (third), etc
Explain the complete change for un/une into masculin: premier/feminin: première (first)
learner_steps: Learners read and pronounce the Ordinal numbers

instructional_blocks.hook: Reading the passage on ordinal numbers and answer the questions
teacher_steps: Provide passage/dialogue for learners to read and pronounce the ordinal numbers
learner_steps: In groups, learners write ordinal numbers from different passages/dialogues provided
Groups present their findings

instructional_blocks.hook: Writing ordinal numbers from 1 to 20
teacher_steps: Guide learners to write ordinal numbers
learner_steps: Learners write ordinal numbers from 1 to 20

sub_topics.short_notes: Formation of ordinal numbers: Add -ième to the cardinal number to get deuxième (second), troisième (third), etc. Complete change for un/une into masculin: premier/feminin: première (first) and spelling adjustment for cinq - cinquième (fifth), neuf - neuvième (ninth). Words ending in 'e' such as quatre, seize, treize drop the 'e' to become quatrième, seizième, and treizième respectively.

questions: Knowledge of ordinal numbers 1 to 20 demonstrated correctly

sub_topics.title: Counting Money
sub_topics.introduction: Money management is an important life skill. By learning about counting money, learners will develop skills that help them budget, save and make smart financial decisions. This sub-topic will also help learners explore mathematical operations and develop skills to manage everyday transactions with confidence.
competences: 1.7.3.1: Apply the four mathematical operations on numbers below 100 in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Adding, Subtracting, Dividing and Multiplying small numbers
teacher_steps: Explain the four mathematical operations - divisé, fois, plus, moins
Provide scenarios on addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division
learner_steps: Learners practice adding small numbers: 2 + 3 = 5 (Deux plus trois égale cinq)
Learners practice subtracting: 7 - 2 = 5 (sept moins deux égale cinq)
Learners practice multiplying: 8 x 3 = 24 (huit fois trois égale vingt-quatre)
Learners practice dividing: 12 ÷ 4 = 3 (Douze divisé par quatre égale trois)

instructional_blocks.hook: Writing a small budget in French
teacher_steps: Provide a sample of a written budget
learner_steps: Learners write a small budget in French (daily or monthly)

sub_topics.short_notes: Mathematical operations in French: plus (addition), moins (subtraction), fois (multiplication), divisé (division), égale (equals). Examples: K10 + K5 = K15 (Dix Kwacha plus Cinq Kwacha égale Quinze Kwacha).

questions: The four mathematical operations applied correctly

topics.overview: Expressing one's preferences is essential for effective daily communication. This skill enables learners to share their interests and engage with others, which is crucial for building relationships. This topic will cover essential vocabulary, key phrases, and sentence structures necessary for discussing preferences.
general_competences: Communication: Develop basic conversational skills to express likes, dislikes, and preferences clearly and confidently in French
Emotional Intelligence: Understand how preferences reflect personality and emotions. Show empathy towards others when discussing likes and dislikes
Critical Thinking: Analyse the reasons behind personal preferences and formulate responses that express these reasons in French
Critical Thinking: Recognize the role of language in shaping and conveying personal preferences
Critical Thinking: Compare and contrast preferences with classmates in order to foster a deeper understanding and appreciation of cultural diversity
topics.hook: Ask learners questions about things they like or dislike. (e.g Qui préfère le chocolat/les bonbons?)

sub_topics.title: Likes and Dislikes
sub_topics.introduction: The subtopic focuses on how to express likes and dislikes in French. Being able to clearly communicate what you like or dislike is essential for both social interactions and personal conversations. By learning these expressions, learners will be able to express their opinions and preferences with confidence.
competences: 1.8.1.1: Express likes and dislikes in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Responding to oral questions on likes and dislikes in French
teacher_steps: Provide verbs and phrases used to express likes and dislikes (e.g., J'aime, Je déteste, Je préfère, Je n'aime pas)
Conjugate the verbs: Aimer, détester, adorer au temps présent
Introduce question words: Qu'est-ce que, quel/quelle est/qui
Explain the negative expression: 'ne … pas' can also be used to express dislikes (subject + ne + verbe + pas)
learner_steps: In pairs, learners practice asking and answering simple questions about their preferences using the verbs and phrases provided

instructional_blocks.hook: Expressing likes and dislikes for taste, colour, hobbies, places, buildings, scenery, people
teacher_steps: Provide a passage/dialogue on likes and dislikes about different things and objects
Provide more examples to help learners express likes and dislikes for each category listed
learner_steps: Learners read and identify different preference expressions/phrases
In pairs, learners practice expressions used to ask about likes and dislikes
In small groups, learners discuss likes and dislikes for taste, colour, hobbies, places, buildings, scenery, people

instructional_blocks.hook: Reading a passage on likes and dislikes and answering questions
teacher_steps: Provide learners with a passage on likes and dislikes
learner_steps: Learners read the passage and answer questions

instructional_blocks.hook: Writing about likes and dislikes in French
teacher_steps: Guide learners to write a coherent paragraph
learner_steps: Learners write a coherent paragraph on their likes and dislikes

sub_topics.short_notes: Expressing likes and dislikes: J'aime (I like), Je déteste (I hate), Je préfère (I prefer), J'adore (I love), Je n'aime pas (I don't like). Question words: Qu'est-ce que tu aimes? (What do you like?), Quel est ton plat préféré? (What is your favorite dish?). Categories include: taste (j'adore la glace), colour (j'aime le bleu), hobbies (j'aime lire), places (j'aime la plage), buildings (j'aime les musées), scenery (j'aime la mer), people (j'adore ma famille). Negation structure: subject + ne + verbe + pas.

topics.overview: In French, localisation refers to the concept of 'where' something is, while movement involves the concept of 'where something is going' or 'how it is moving'. This topic discusses the position of an object, person, or thing in a sentence. It is a crucial topic for learners because it equips them with the vocabulary, expressions and grammatical structures needed for describing position, direction and distance.
general_competences: Communication: Apply listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills
Communication: Express oneself (spoken and written) clearly and effectively using prepositions of place
Communication: Express oneself using different media and symbols of something object or person
Analytical thinking: Use appropriate language (Verbal and non-verbal) in different situations when giving directions and locating the position of something
Emotional Intelligence: Learners will use appropriate expressions and show empathy when asking for direction
topics.hook: How do you ask for direction and location of a place you have never been to?

sub_topics.title: Position
sub_topics.introduction: Position is defined as the location or placement of an object, person, and point in relation to its surrounding. It describes where something is situated physically.
competences: 1.9.1.1: Describe the position of an object in French
1.9.1.2: State the location of a person, place or thing in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Identifying preposition of place from a given passage/demonstration
teacher_steps: Provide a passage with prepositions of place
Demonstrate and explain the meaning of each preposition used in the passage by using objects in class with different prepositions of place
learner_steps: Learners read the passage on prepositions of place (sur, dans, sous)
Learners identify different positions of objects in a given picture

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing the position of the object in relation to another
teacher_steps: Introduce other prepositions and explain their meaning to the learners (derrière, devant, à côté de)
Provide any two objects to be described in relation to each other
Position the two objects
Place different objects in different positions in relation to the other by using (devant, a cote, derriere, au, dessous)
learner_steps: Learners construct sentences on the position of an object in relation to the other

instructional_blocks.hook: Locating a place or person on a given map or drawing
teacher_steps: Provide a map or a chart with people, buildings, roads and symbols correctly marked
Explain how to use 'se trouver' in a sentence when giving a response
learner_steps: Learners identify landmarks such as hôtel, restaurant, banque, hopital, Rue Cairo on the map by naming them
Learners identify where a person, place or thing is located on the map in relation to buildings, roads
Learners respond to questions on positions of people, places or things using the map and the vocabulary learned

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing the campus (l'Est, Ouest, Nord, Sud)
teacher_steps: Introduce the four cardinal points of the campus (le Sud, le Nord, l'Est, l'Ouest)
learner_steps: Learners draw the campus and label the points in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Locating the provinces of Zambia and their headquarters
teacher_steps: Guide learners to name the 10 provinces of Zambia and their headquarters in French
learner_steps: Learners name the 10 provinces of Zambia and their headquarters in French
Learners match provinces to different activities found in each province

sub_topics.short_notes: Prepositions of place: sur (on), dans (in), sous (under), devant (in front of), derrière (behind), à côté de (next to), entre (between), près de (near), loin de (far from), en face de (opposite), à gauche (on the left), à droite (on the right). Cardinal points: le Nord (North), le Sud (South), l'Est (East), l'Ouest (West). Using 'se trouver' to indicate location: Notre école se trouve près de la banque (Our school is located near the bank).

questions: Position of an object described correctly
Location of a thing, place, and people stated in French accordingly

sub_topics.title: Direction
sub_topics.introduction: Directions are instructions or guidance on how to navigate from one place to another. They help learners understand where they are, where they need to go, and how to get there. Asking for and giving directions in French is an essential skill used in everyday conversations.
competences: 1.9.2.1: Give directions to someone in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Listening to a dialogue on giving directions and identifying expressions used
teacher_steps: Provide dialogue/conversation in which two people are asking for and giving directions
Demonstrate giving directions by using a sketch map with places, roads and symbols
learner_steps: Learners listen to the conversation or dialogue and identify expressions used when asking and giving directions
Learners practice giving direction using specific destinations of their choice

instructional_blocks.hook: Reading a simple map and locating a place/village/town/any other features
teacher_steps: Introduce more expressions used to ask for and give directions in French
Explain l'emploi de: à, à l', à la, au
Provide and display a map showing different places and ask learners to locate the places mentioned
learner_steps: Learners role play asking for and giving directions using the expressions learned

instructional_blocks.hook: Directing someone to a given place
teacher_steps: Guide learners to ask for and give directions
learner_steps: In pairs, learners ask for and give directions using correct expressions learned

instructional_blocks.hook: Giving directions to ones own place of choice in written
teacher_steps: Guide learners to write a composition
learner_steps: Learners write a guided composition directing someone to their own place of choice

sub_topics.short_notes: Asking for directions: Où se trouve l'hôpital? (Where is the hospital?), Où est l'église s'il vous plaît? (Where is the church please?), Excusez-moi, Je cherche la banque ZANACO (Excuse me, I'm looking for ZANACO bank), Je suis perdu(e), c'est où le centre commercial? (I'm lost, where is the shopping center?). Giving directions: Allez tout droit (Go straight ahead), Continuez tout droit (Continue straight ahead), Tournez à droite/à gauche (Turn right/left), Prenez la première route à droite (Take the first road on the right), Traversez la rue/le pont (Cross the street/bridge). Using à, à l', à la, au to indicate direction to a place.

questions: Directions given to someone in French precisely

sub_topics.title: Distance
sub_topics.introduction: Distance is a common topic in everyday conversations. Whether someone is asking how far a location is or discussing travel plans, knowing how to express distance allows one to engage in these conversations naturally. This sub-topic will discuss French expressions that are important in describing locations and directions.
competences: 1.9.3.1: Indicate how far or near a point is from another in French

instructional_blocks.hook: Identifying expressions indicating how far or near a point is from another
teacher_steps: Provide expressions used to talk about distance in French
learner_steps: Learners identify expressions used to indicate distance between two points from a given passage

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing distance between two points
teacher_steps: Display a plan or map showing distances between two places
learner_steps: Learners discuss how far the two places are from each other
In groups, learners construct sentences using 'près de, loin de, à … kilomètre de'
In pairs, learners role-play using expressions used to indicate distance between two points in French

sub_topics.short_notes: Asking about distance: À quelle distance de Lusaka se trouve Solwezi? (How far from Lusaka is Solwezi?), C'est à quelle distance? (How far is it?), À combien de kilomètres de Chinsali? (How many kilometers from Chinsali?). Expressing distance: Il y a 7 kilomètres de Chipata à Katete (There are 7 kilometers from Chipata to Katete), C'est à 20 kilomètres de Choma à Mazabuka (It's 20 kilometers from Choma to Mazabuka), près de (near), loin de (far from).

questions: Distance between two points indicated clearly

topics.overview: Accommodation and hygiene are two sides of the same coin that are closely linked to environment awareness. Hygiene plays a crucial role in ensuring good health, comfort and overall well-being. Understanding the importance of accommodation and hygiene helps learners to take care of their surroundings and make informed choices about where they live and how to maintain their environment.
general_competences: Communication: Learners will acquire necessary vocabulary to engage in environmental discussions
Critical thinking: Learners will develop environmental awareness that will enable them to make right decision on issues to do with their environment
Environmental Sustainability: Learners will uphold good practices that benefit and sustain their environment
topics.hook: Show two pictures showing dirty environment and ask learners to guess words for dirty and clean in French.

sub_topics.title: Types of Homes
sub_topics.introduction: A home is a place where a person or family lives. It provides shelter, safety, comfort and a sense of belonging. A home can be a house, a hut or any space where people feel secure and at ease. It is more than just a building, it is where people eat, sleep, rest and spend time with loved ones. This sub topic explores different types of homes notably modern and traditional homes.
competences: 1.10.1.1: Compare modern and traditional houses in French
1.10.1.2: Name different rooms and their use in a house

instructional_blocks.hook: Identify the difference between a modern and traditional houses
teacher_steps: Show pictures of different types of houses (traditional and modern)
Explain the traditional and modern types of houses in French
Explain the structures: Il y a (there is), Y a t-il? (is there?)
Explain the Prepositions en (made of), au (à+ le) (at), Dans (in)
Conclude with a matching activity
Provide a list of material used for traditional and modern houses in French
learner_steps: Learners describe and identify modern and traditional houses in the pictures provided
In groups, learners name the types of houses they know
Learners draw and colour the two different types of houses
Learners classify the materials according to the types of houses

instructional_blocks.hook: Reading a passage on modern and traditional houses and summarize the features
teacher_steps: Provide a passage on characteristics of modern and traditional homes
learner_steps: Learners read a given passage and answer the questions

instructional_blocks.hook: Describing modern and traditional houses in writing
teacher_steps: Guide learners to write a short composition
learner_steps: Learners write a short-guided composition describing their homes or houses

instructional_blocks.hook: Naming different rooms in a house and their use
teacher_steps: Provide a sketch map of a house with different rooms (salle à coucher, salon)
Explain the use of each room in the house (chambre - dormir, salon - regarder la télévision)
learner_steps: In groups, learners name items found in each room
Learners match different rooms with their corresponding uses

instructional_blocks.hook: Describing one's own house in French
teacher_steps: Guide learners to describe their houses and rooms
learner_steps: Learners describe their houses and rooms by using different descriptive adjectives

instructional_blocks.hook: Writing a short-guided composition on a house of your choice
teacher_steps: Guide learners to write a composition
learner_steps: Learners write a short composition on a house of their choice and describe the rooms

sub_topics.short_notes: Types of houses: Traditional (Traditionnelle): Une maison en bous (grass house), Une maison en bois (wooden house), Une maison en terre battue (mud house). Modern (Moderne): Une maison en brique (brick house), Une maison en étage (storey building). Structures: Il y a (there is/are), Y a t-il? (is there?). Prepositions: en (made of), au (at), dans (in). Rooms: les chambres (rooms), la chambre à coucher (bedroom), le salon (living room), la salle de bain (bathroom), la salle à manger (dining room), la cuisine (kitchen), les toilettes (toilet), la douche (shower).

questions: Modern and traditional houses compared in French correctly
Different rooms in a house and their use identified accordingly

sub_topics.title: Care for the Surrounding
sub_topics.introduction: Living in a clean and conducive environment is key to good health. It is very important to take extra care of our surroundings in order to promote sound health. This sub topic focuses on the activities, hygiene behavioral changes and tools that are needed to maintain a good surrounding.
competences: 1.10.2.1: Describe a clean and dirty place

instructional_blocks.hook: Describing a clean and dirty place in French
teacher_steps: Provide two pictures. One showing a clean place and the other a dirty one
Explain the key words describing a clean and dirty place (propre, sale)
learner_steps: Learners compare the two pictures provided in groups
Learners describe the two pictures using the French vocabulary learned

instructional_blocks.hook: Use the verb 'être' to indicate that a place is clean or dirty
teacher_steps: Guide learners to discuss whether their class or school is clean or dirty
learner_steps: In groups, learners discuss whether their class or school is clean or dirty in French
Learners write a short paragraph describing a clean or a dirty place of their choice

instructional_blocks.hook: Discussing ways of keeping the surrounding clean
teacher_steps: Conjugate the verbs: balayer, travailler, nettoyer, faire and jeter in present tense
Explain ways of keeping the surrounding clean
Provide a passage on ways of keeping a surrounding clean
learner_steps: In groups, learners discuss the passage on ways of keeping the surrounding clean
Learners write a summary on ways of keeping the surrounding clean

instructional_blocks.hook: Identifying materials used for keeping the surrounding clean
teacher_steps: Provide a list of assorted items found in a house in French
Introduce materials used for cleaning an environment (le balai, le torchon, la houe, la pelle)
learner_steps: In groups, learners identify the materials used to clean the surroundings from the provided list
Learners draw and label the cleaning materials in French
Learners translate the learned vocabulary into English

instructional_blocks.hook: Stating negative effects of dirty surroundings
teacher_steps: Explain negative effects of dirty surroundings
Provide a text depicting the negative effects of dirty environments
learner_steps: In groups, learners read and discuss the passage on the negative effects of dirty surroundings
Learners write a note summary on the negative effects of living in a dirty surroundings

instructional_blocks.hook: Mentioning ways of keeping oneself clean
teacher_steps: Explain ways of keeping personal hygiene
Guide learners on how to construct simple sentences on personal hygiene in French
Provide a short passage on personal hygiene
learner_steps: Learners answer questions based on the given passage
Learners write a short paragraph on ways to keep oneself clean

instructional_blocks.hook: Drawing materials used for personal hygiene
teacher_steps: Provide a list of materials used for personal hygiene in French
learner_steps: Learners draw and label materials used for personal hygiene and make talking walls or a photo gallery

instructional_blocks.hook: Writing dictated words in French
teacher_steps: Dictate words on personal hygiene
learner_steps: Learners write dictated words of the learned vocabulary on personal hygiene

sub_topics.short_notes: Describing cleanliness: propre (clean), sale (dirty), frais/fraîche (fresh), organisé (organized), brillant (shiny). Ways to keep surroundings clean: balayer (sweep), nettoyer (clean), jeter les déchets dans la poubelle (throw trash in the bin), arroser les fleurs (water the flowers), recycler les plastics (recycle plastics). Cleaning materials: le balai (broom), le torchon (mop), la houe (hoe), la pelle (shovel), l'eau (water), la poubelle (trash bin). Negative effects: contracter le choléra (contract cholera), la toux (cough), la dysenterie (dysentery).
